name: Gmail Add-on Phish Alert Button (PAB) Guide
title: Gmail Add-on Phish Alert Button (PAB) Guide
body:
Your organization may have recently installed the Gmail Add-on Phish Alert Button (PAB). In this article, you will learn how this tool works and how you can use it to help keep your organization safe from malicious phishing emails.

When to Use the PAB

You should select the PAB anytime you suspect that you have received a phishing email or any potentially dangerous email. The emails you report may also be forwarded to a designated contact within your organization for analysis.

How to Use the PAB

You can use the PAB icon to report any email as a phishing email, but you cannot use the PAB to report multiple emails at once. You should report each potential phishing email individually. However, if you report an email that has multiple emails associated with it, all of the associated emails will be reported as well.

Gmail Inbox

To use the PAB add-on in your Gmail inbox, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Gmail account on your web browser.
  2. Open the email that you would like to report.
  3. Open the add-on menu on the right side of your Google inbox and select the phish hook icon to open the PAB add-on.

  4. (Optional) You can also add comments and select a disposition to provide more information about the email.

  5. Select the blue Phish Alert button to report the email.

  6. Once the confirmation message appears, select the back arrow to go back to your inbox. The reported email will be moved to the Trash folder.
    Note:If you're viewing an email in split pane mode, the back arrow is not available. You can change your Gmail inbox settings to make the back arrow visible. You can also select Inbox or your browser's back arrow to go back to your inbox.

Gmail Mobile

To use the PAB add-on from the Gmail app on your mobile device, follow the instructions below.

  1. Log in to the Gmail app on your mobile device.
  2. Open the email that you would like to report.
  3. Scroll to the bottom of the screen and locate the available add-ons section.
  4. From the add-ons section, select the phish hook icon and scroll down to the bottom of the screen to access the PAB.

  5. Select the blue Report button to report the email.

  6. If enabled, you will see a confirmation message, and the email will be moved to your Trash folder.

  7. Select the back arrow to return to your inbox.

Reason to Use the PAB

Reporting emails will help your organization stay safe. Because the potential phishing emails you report are sent to your organization for analysis, your organization will be aware of which phishing attacks are able to reach their users' inboxes. Once everyone is aware of possible vulnerabilities, they can better defend against cyber attacks. You are an important part of the process of keeping your organization safe from cybercriminals. Stop, look, and think!

This image displays the full-screen desktop view of a received email within the Google Gmail web interface.

**UI Environment:**
The interface utilizes a dark grey desktop background visible through the application window. The user is logged in under the "knowbe4 D" profile and is marked as "Active." The standard Gmail layout includes a left navigation rail (Mail, Chat, Meet) and a right-hand sidebar containing application shortcuts (Calendar, Keep, Tasks, and a non-standard orange hook icon).

**Email Metadata and Controls:**
The email is titled **"Email Server Migration Failure"** and is marked with the label **"Inbox."** A prominent suggestion button, **"Summarize this email,"** is visible beneath the subject line. The email header shows the sender as **"IT <IT@knowbe4.com>"** addressed "to User." The message was received on **"Mon, Nov 3, 2:29 PM (3 days ago)."** Standard action icons (Star, Reply, More Options) are present in the top right of the message pane.

**Email Content (Body Text):**
The message text addresses a technical failure:
1.  **Context:** "The IT Department was running an email server migration last night and encountered an error with several email accounts. Your account happened to be one of them."
2.  **Resolution Request:** "We attempted to resolve this problem and believe we have fixed it. If your email has been working just fine, please let us know by going to this secure **website** and validate your email address is working." (The word "website" is rendered as a blue, underlined hyperlink, but the destination URL is obscured.)
3.  **Sign-off:** The email concludes with "Thanks for your quick cooperation, IT."

**User Interaction Elements:**
Three standard response buttons are displayed at the bottom of the email body: **Reply**, **Reply all**, and **Forward**.

*   **Comment Input:** A text input field beneath the classification options contains the user-entered text: "This looks like a phish."

The image displays a screenshot of an email thread on a mobile device, likely within a Gmail application interface.

**Header and Subject:** The email is titled, "Scheduled Tests on Your Computer." It is labeled with a yellow "External" tag and a grey "Inbox" tag. The top navigation bar includes icons for Archive, Delete, and More Options.

**Sender Information:** The email is from "Ron W." sent at "19:58."

**Email Body:**
The text claims the sender, identifying as "Ron," is a Senior Technician with "ISP Services" who was contacted by the recipient's IT department to run diagnostic tests.
The core instruction is: "In order to complete my tests I need you to please visit **this site** [hyperlink], download the test files, and run them on your computer. Just click Run when prompted. The program will send some information back to me and then delete itself."
The signature reads: "R. Weasley, Senior Technician, ISP Services."

**UI Elements (Bottom):**
Below the email body are Smart Reply buttons: "Will do.", "Thank you, I will do that.", and "Done."
Standard email interaction buttons include: "Reply," "Reply all," and "Forward."

**Footer and Action Icon:**
The footer area includes the text "Available add-ons:". A red arrow explicitly points to a circular action button located on the bottom right, which contains a stylized fish hook icon. This icon typically represents the "Report Phishing" function in the application.

**Header and Status Bar:**
*   **Time:** 20:00.
*   **System Icons:** Icons for Wi-Fi, battery, and notifications are visible, along with a front-facing camera cutout (punch hole design).
*   **App Navigation:** Icons for back arrow, archive, delete, mark unread, and a three-dot menu (top right) are present.

**Email Details:**
*   **Subject:** "Scheduled Tests on Your Computer".
*   **Labels:** Two adjacent labels are displayed: "External" (yellow background) and "Inbox" (white/light background).
*   **Sender:** "Ron W."
*   **Timestamp:** 19:58.
*   **Recipient:** "to me".

**Email Body Content (Key Phishing Elements):**
*   The email claims to be from a "local Internet Service Provider" assisting the recipient's "IT department."
*   It instructs the user to "visit this site, download the test files, and run them on your computer."
*   It further states, "The program will send some information back to me and then delete itself." The word "site" is hyperlinked (blue text).

**Security Add-on/Detection Interface:**
*   Below the main email content, a section titled "Available add-ons:" appears.
*   **Highlighted Area (Phishing Indicator):** An orange arrow points from the text body to a stylized, orange fishing hook icon enclosed in a circle, indicating a detected phishing link or threat (likely as part of a training exercise).
*   **Add-on Banner:** A prominent blue banner is labeled "Phish Alert."
*   **Reporting Interface:** Below the banner, the identity "KnowBe4 Inc." is shown, accompanied by an icon of an envelope with a fishing hook. The adjacent text is "Report Email."
*   **Confirmation Prompt:** A prompt asks, "Are you sure you want to report this as a phishing email?"
*   **Footer Details:** The subject is repeated under a "SUBJECT:" label. A button labeled "SHOW SENDER'S DETAILS" is displayed at the bottom of the visible screen.

The image displays a smartphone screen showing an email opened within a mobile application (likely Gmail). The email is titled **"Scheduled Tests on Your Computer"** and is labeled as **"External"** and **"Inbox."**

*   **Body:** The sender claims to be with a local Internet Service Provider, contacted by the recipient's IT department to run diagnostic tests. The email instructs the user to click a hyperlinked word (**"this site"**), download test files, run them, and notes that "The program will send some information back to me and then delete itself."

**UI Elements and Context:**

1.  **Header/Navigation Bar (Top):** Displays time (**20:00**), status icons (Wi-Fi, battery, etc.), and standard email actions: Back arrow, Archive icon, Delete (Trash) icon, Mark as Unread icon, and a three-dot More options menu.
2.  **Email Actions (Mid-Right):** Includes a Star icon (to mark as favorite) and a curved Reply arrow with a three-dot menu for additional message actions.

    *   **Unselected:** "Unknown - I'm not sure how to describe this email."

5.  **Action Button:** A large, prominent blue button at the bottom reads **"REPORT."** A red arrow is overlaid on the image, pointing specifically to this "REPORT" button, indicating the intended user action.
